context: Without doubt, adjusted levels of benzene, ethylbenzene, o-xylene, and m/p-xylene have decreases over the study period of 2005–2012 and smokers do have several fold higher levels of these VOCs when compared with nonsmokers. Thus, a natural question to ask would be to know if decline has been uniform among both smokers and nonsmokers or either smokers or nonsmokers have primarily contributed to these declines. An attempt was made to address this curiosity. Model predicted levels of benzene, ethylbenzene, o-xylene, STY, TOL, and m/p-xylene were computed separately for smokers and nonsmokers and tested for trends over time and the results are provided in supplementary Table S10. As can be seen, there were only minor differences among smokers and nonsmokers in the percentage decline for every two-year period. For example, for benzene, percentage decline among smokers was 16.6% and 18.6% among nonsmokers. Hence, observed declines in the levels of these VOCs cannot primarily be attributed to smokers or nonsmokers.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, ethylbenzene and 4-xylene are both mentioned as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) whose levels have decreased over the study period from 2005 to 2012. The study compares the levels of these VOCs in smokers and nonsmokers, indicating that both groups experienced similar declines in ethylbenzene and 4-xylene levels. However, the specific relationship between ethylbenzene and 4-xylene is not explored in detail, as the focus is on their trends in relation to smoking status rather than their direct interaction or significance.
